title.narrative: OPT 2.2. INNOVATIVE AND FLEXIBLE LEARNIN

description.narrative: The education system, particularly in the four departments receiving UNICEF support, have increased capacity to plan, implement and monitor innovative and flexible learning modalities for vulnerable and marginalised adolescents., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Learning Outcomes, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, children and adolescents, especially the most disadvantaged, have increased access to, learning and completion of quality education services, including in emergency situations.

participating-org.narrative: INSTITUTO PLURINACIONAL DE ESTUDIO DE LENGUAS Y CULTURAS IPELC

sector.narrative: System strengthening - Evidence based education sector planning
System strengthening - curricula and learning materials design (excluding early-learning / pre-primary)
System strengthening - inclusive education for other vulnerable children poorest quintile, ethnic/linguistic minorities, migrant children, non-citizens/undocumented children etc.
System strengthening - mainstreaming of skills development within national education/training system

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: The education system, particularly in the four departments receiving UNICEF support, have increased capacity to plan, implement andmonitor innovative and flexible learning modalities for vulnerable and marginalised adolescents.

description.narrative: More than 22,000 teachers (16% of the total teaching staff) across the country increased their capacities to offer virtual education, including in emergency situations, which complies with a humanitarian-development nexus approach. In total 3,218 girls and adolescents in vulnerable situations benefited from programmes to increase their knowledge of digital skills and reduce the digital gender gap, while 200 adolescents (94 girls, 106 boys) accessed virtual education, preventing them from dropping out of school. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:22/12/2021
